questions.question: A man is referred for fever and agitation for the past 4 days. Examination reveals adisoriented man who is unable to swallow water due to involuntary inspiratory musclespasms of the pharynx. He had been bitten by a dog 3 months ago but was not treated. Whatgenus does the causative organism of this condition belong to?
Which of the following is false about the fixed virus of rabies?

options.C: Does not multiply in extra neural tissues

questions.explanation: The fixed virus has a short incubation period.There are 2 types of rabies viruses:Fixed virusIsolated after several intracerebral passages in rabbitsShort, fixed, and reproducible incubation period of 6 to 7daysDoes not form Negri bodies or multiply in extraneural tissuesUsed in the preparation of live-attenuatedanti-rabies vacciStreet virusIsolated from naturally occurring cases of rabiesThe incubation period is longand highly variable between 1to 12 weeksForms Negri bodies and multiplies in extraneural tissuesIt is the primary cause of rabies diseasene

questions.question: Which of the following does not lead to the transmission of rabies to humans?

options.A: Nibbling by an infected animal on abraded skin
options.C: Direct contact of infected saliva with the mucosa
options.D: Ingestion of raw meat of infected animal

questions.explanation: Ingestion of the raw meat of the infected animal does not lead to the transmission of rabies.285Mammals like dogs and bats are important animal sources. The important modes of transmissionof rabies are as follows:• Scratches or deep bites• Exposure of infected saliva to intact mucosa or fresh skin woundsHuman–to–human transmission through bites has never been confirmed.

questions.question: You have witnessed your neighbor being bitten by a rabid dog. You should advise him to washthe wound with soap and water for a minimum of:279
questions.explanation: Following dog bites, the bite wound should be washed with soap under running tap water for 15minutes.Local treatment of the bite wound is essential for the prevention of rabies and can reduce theinfection rate by up to 80%. The following steps must be followed:•Cleansing: Washing under running water with soap or irrigation with a catheter in case of deepwounds• Chemical agent: Alcohol or tincture /0.01% aqueous solution of iodine or povidone-iodine iseffective for inactivation of residual virus• Suturing: Must be done only following 24-48 hours if necessary, under the cover of rabiesimmunoglobulin locally and minimal stitches• Antibiotics and anti-tetanus measures when indicated

questions.question: A worker at a veterinary hospital has just received the 1st dose of rabies vaccine as apre-exposure prophylactic measure. When should he return for the remaining doses?
questions.explanation: Pre-exposure prophylaxis for rabies consists of 3 doses to be given on days 0, 7, and 21 or28. They are given intramuscularly or intradermally in the deltoid area of the arm.High-risk groups like laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, andtravelers to endemic regions are candidates for pre-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy was bitten by a suspected rabid dog. On examination, there are minorscratches and abrasions without bleeding. Which of the following is true about the categoryand management of the wound?

options.A: Category II - Local treatment of wound with povidone and follow up
options.B: Category III - Local treatment of wound and give ARV and antibiotics
options.C: Category II - Local treatment of wound and give ARV
options.D: Category III - Give ARV and anti-rabies immunoglobulin

questions.explanation: Minor scratches and abrasions without bleeding are classified under category II wounds. CategoryII wounds are managed by immediate local treatment of wound and vaccination (ARV).Antibiotics are not required in case of minor scratches and abrasions.

questions.question: A public health worker was brought with multiple transdermal dog bites. He tells you that hehad received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago. What is the next best step inmanagement?

options.C: Wound washing and ARV with half dose of RIG
options.D: Wound treatment and ARV; RIG is not required280

questions.explanation: This given clinical scenario of a patient with multiple transdermal dog bites would be categorisedunder category III. As the patient received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago, his line of286•management includes the following:• Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 minutes and application of antiseptic• Anti-rabies vaccine 2 doses on day o and day 3, with either intradermal vaccine(0.1ml, 1 site) orintramuscular vaccine(1 vial, 1site).There is no requirement for Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG), if previous pre-exposure prophylaxisor post exposure prophylaxis documentation is available. If documentation of PEP or PrEP isunavailable, patient should be treated as fresh case and given full PEP.

questions.question: An 8-year-old child was brought with an unprovoked dog bite. Which of the followingmeasures should be taken?

options.A: Withhold the vaccine and observe the dog for 10 days
options.B: Give half the dose of the vaccine

questions.explanation: This child should be given immediate post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) by administering a cellculture-derived vaccine to reduce the chances of getting rabies.

questions.question: A 5-year-old boy had received a full course rabies vaccine taken in December 2018. His petdog which has been fully vaccinated now (November 2019) bit him on the toe. Bleeding waspresent at the site of the bite. What would be the line of treatment?

options.B: 2 doses of vaccine on Day o & 3

questions.explanation: This boy should receive 2 doses of vaccine on days o & 3 as he has received a prior course ofpost-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) > 3 months ago.Management of a new dog bite in a previously immunized individual with either pre-exposureprophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is as follows:•••Category I: Wound treatment onlyCategory II/III:Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 min and apply antiseptic• Receive Anti-rabies vaccine (ARV) 2 doses ID (0.1 ml, 1 site)/ 2 doses IM (1 VIAL, 1 site) ondays o and 3.*Note: In developing countries like India, the vaccination status of animals alone, doesn't play asignificant role in determining the initiation of prophylaxis in humans.

questions.question: What is the incubation period of yellow fever?
questions.explanation: The incubation period of yellow fever is 3-6 days.

questions.question: According to the International Health Regulations, an Aedes aegypti index of which of thefollowing must be maintained to achieve zero risk of spread of yellow fever?
questions.explanation: The Aedes aegypti index should be < 1% in endemic areas to achieve zero risk of spread ofyellow fever.The Aedes aegypti index is a type of house index. It refers to the percentage of houses andpremises in a limited well-defined area with actual breeding of Aedes aegypti larvae.287

questions.question: A woman is planning a trip to Morocco, which is endemic for yellow fever. As per travelregulations, she receives the yellow fever vaccine. After how many days following vaccinationis she eligible to travel?
questions.explanation: This woman is eligible to travel to the endemic area 10 days after being vaccinated for yellowfever. This period is required for the majority of vaccine recipients to develop immunity.The 17D vaccine for yellow fever is given subcutaneously. Unvaccinated people are required toremain quarantined for 6 days (maximum period of incubation).

questions.question: Which of the following is the yellow fever reference center in India?
questions.explanation: The reference centers for yellow fever in India are as follows:• Central Research Institute, Kasauli• National Institute of Virology, Pune

questions.question: An outbreak of Kyasanur forest disease occurred among a group of forest officers inKarnataka. Which of the following vectors should be targeted to prevent the further spread ofthe disease?
questions.explanation: Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) is transmitted by the bite of infective hard ticks of Haemaphysalisspecies. Hence, control of ticks must be done to prevent spread of the disease.KFD is a hemorrhagic febrile disease caused by a flavivirus. Man is an incidental dead-end host inthe life cycle of the vector (hard tick). Small mammals like rodents and squirrels are the reservoirswhile monkeys serve as the amplifier hosts. KFD is endemic in 4 districts of Karnataka (Shimoga,North Kannada, South Kannada, Chikmagalur).The incubation period is between 3 to 8 days. The disease presents with sudden onset of fever,headache, myalgia. In severe cases, gastrointestinal disturbances and hemorrhages from the nose,gums, stomach, and intestine may occur. The case fatality rate is 5 to 10%.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route?
questions.explanation: Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons). The basiccycles of transmission are:(a)Pig → Mosquito → Pig(b) BirdMosquito → BirdHumans are incidental "dead-end" hosts and are infected by the bite of infected Culex mosquitoes.288

questions.question: Which following is false about Japanese encephalitis?

options.A: Man is the incidental dead-end host
options.B: Culicines act as vectors for this condition
options.D: It is caused by a group B arbovirus

questions.explanation: The incubation period of Japanese encephalitis (JE) in man following a mosquito bite is 5-15 days.JE is mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by a group B arbovirus (Flavivirus). It is transmitted byCulex (culicine) mosquitoes mainly C.tritaeniorhynchus and C.vishnui. Ardeid birds (herons) arethe reservoirs while pigs are the amplifier hosts. Man is an incidental dead-end host. Man-to-mantransmission has not been recorded.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about Japanese encephalitis?

options.A: SA-14-14-2 strain vaccine is commonly used
options.B: Diagnosis is confirmed by CSF culture
options.C: Patients usually recover without any sequelae

questions.explanation: SA-14-14-2 strain vaccine is used for the prevention of Japanese encephalitis (JE).Japanese encephalitis (JE) is mosquito-borne encephalitis caused by a group B arbovirus(Flavivirus) and transmitted by Culex mosquitoes. Most individuals develop subclinical infection.The course of disease in man divided into 3 stages:••• Prodromal stage - fever, headache, gastrointestinal disturbances, lethargy, and malaise• Acute encephalitic stage - high-grade fever, nuchal rigidity, convulsions, signs of raisedintracranial pressure, paralysis, altered sensorium•Late-stage and sequelae - neurological or psychiatric sequelae seen in up to 50% of survivorsDiagnosis is serological, using blood or CSF samples. The virus rarely grows in culture. The casefatality rate varies between 20-40%. There are 3 types of JE vaccines available:.••Nakayama or Beijing strain - purified inactivated vaccineBeijing P-3 strain - inactivated vaccineSA-14-14-2 - live attenuated vaccineNote: Killed JE vaccines (Inactivated SA 14-14-2 cell culture-derived and inactivated Vero cellculture-derived) are gradually replacing live attenuated vaccines. According to the nationalimmunisation schedule, both live attenuated, killed-inactivated vaccines are now used forvaccination against the JE virus.

questions.question: The life cycle of which of the following is depicted in the image below?283
questions.explanation: The given image depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus.Nipah virus is an RNA virus that belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae, genus Henipavirus. It isa zoonotic virus that shows both animal-to-human (bats, pigs) and human-to-humantransmission. The natural hosts are fruit bats of the Pteropodidae family.The clinical manifestations include asymptomatic subclinical infection, acute respiratoryinfection, and fatal encephalitis. There is no treatment or vaccine available for either people oranimals. The primary treatment for humans is supportive care.Nipah virus is on the WHO list of Blueprint priority diseases.289290
